task: Identify and pick up the lighter block and move it to the opposite end of the table*.
Methodically stack block A on top of block B regardless of their weight, in an attempt to maximize their combined height.
Pick and hold block A and shake it gently without dropping it to understand the nature and density of the block's material.*
Using the force sensor, apply a specific amount of force against block B, moving it a certain distance across the table.
Experiment with picking up both the blocks at the same time, maintaining the grip throughout without dropping any block.
Arrange the blocks parallel to each other with the longer sides facing each other, irrespective of the block size.
Tilt block B to a 45-degree angle without moving it off the table.
With the help of the end effector, try to flip block A upside down to show its bottom surface*.
Identify the larger block based on size and place it on the smaller block in order to create a steady balance*.
Stack block B on top of block A in a way that the blocks align perfectly with each other without any part hanging at the edges*.
Pick up block A and place it on the opposite side of the table.
Stack block B on top of block A without altering block A's original position*.
Using the end effector, tap block A three times without moving block B from its initial location*.
Slide block B around the table's surface for a total distance of one meter*.
Pick up block A and rotate it 360 degrees in the gripper before placing it down at its original position.
Move block B to block A's initial position without toppling block A over*.
Pick up block A and place it directly on top of block B, stacked perfectly upright*.
Use the parallel gripper to hand over block A from one side of the workspace to the other side in a straight line.
Squeeze block A with increasing force without lifting it, until the force reading on the end effector reaches a pre-set level*.
Switch places of blocks A and B, ensuring that the blocks end in the same orientation they began with*.
Stack block A on top of block B without inducing a net force change exceeding 5N on the force sensor.*
Repeatedly hand over block A from the left gripper to the right gripper without dropping it.
Move block B to the edge of the table and bring it back to the center without tipping it over.*
Exchange the positions of the two blocks without touching the table.
Arrange block B in a position relative to block A, where both are balanced on opposing corners.*
Rotate block A 180 degrees around its center axis without changing its position on the table.*
Determine the heavier block by lifting each block by a certain height. Then place the lighter block on top of the heavier one*.
Test the robustness of the gripper by applying varying loadings using block A and recording the force on the force sensor.*
Position block B such that its center of mass is directly over the center of block A.*
Determine the most stable orientation for block A by placing it at different orientations and recording the force on the force sensor.*
Stack block A on top of block B regardless of their weight.
Drop the heavier block on top of the lighter one such that the lighter block sustains minimum damage.*
Move block B to the edge of the table without letting it fall.*
Position the two blocks next to each other in such a way that they touch each other from the largest flat surfaces.*
Arrange the blocks in ascending order of their mass starting from the left side of the table.*
Flip block A upside down without touching block B.*
Stack block B over block A only if block B is lighter.*
Move block A to the right-most corner of the table.*
Align the two blocks by one of their sides making sure they don't overlap.*
Maximize the distance between the two blocks on the table.*
Pick up block A and place it on block B without tipping over block B*.
Arrange block A and block B side by side on the table with block A on the right and block B on the left*.
Determine which block is denser based by lifting each block and comparing the force sensor readings*.
Stack block A directly on top of block B without tilting either block*.
Reorder the blocks from left to right on the table based on their weight, with the heavier block on the left*.
Pick up and then release block B from a predefined height to simulate a drop test*.
Rotate block B 90 degrees clockwise while keeping it in its initial position*.
Move block A to the leftmost area of the table and block B to the rightmost area without changing their initial orientations*.
Balance block B on top of block A, without any part of block B hanging over the edge of block A*.
Move block A to the front right corner of the table and block B to the rear left corner, considering the skewed view from the Franka robot's placement*.
